Award.AwardTitle: Continuing Support for the LTER Network Office
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural ecosystems experience constant change, and the consequences of this change are often revealed gradually over long periods of time. Twenty-five active Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) projects collect the long-term data necessary to identify these consequences and their effects on the ecosystem services, such as provision of clean water, that are critical for society. The LTER Network Office provides information management, communication, and logistic services to advance LTER research. This project will continue these services for one year while a new National Office is selected and becomes operational. The project will advance the field of ecosystem ecology by organizing multidisciplinary meetings and by providing the information management services needed to ensure public access to LTER data. Activities over the coming year will increase the amount and diversity of ecological data available to the scientific community, policy makers, resource managers, and the public, and will facilitate understanding of the nature and pace of ecological change.

The researchers will organize people, tools, and ideas to promote understanding of ecological systems from local to global scales. The Science Council meeting will initiate network-level syntheses leading to scientific publications and presentations, lay the groundwork for broad community-wide participation in a triennial All Scientists Meeting, and address issues critical to the long-term stability and success of the LTER Network. Outcomes from the All Scientists Meeting will include the formation of new collaborations with programs outside of the LTER community, the development of new LTER science themes, and better integration of graduate students and early-career scientists into the LTER community. Continued support of the LTER Network Information System will increase the amount and diversity of ecological data available to the scientific community and observation networks such as the National Ecological Observatory Network (NEON) for comparison and synthesis. The researchers will provide leadership in the important areas of data sharing, data standards, connectivity, and the acquisition and implementation of new technologies through relationships with other distributed networks and research programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The principal goal of the Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) Network is to understand change in the natural world, especially those changes that take place so subtly that they might not be noticed by the average observer.  By studying ecosystems over many generations, the LTER Network identifies changes that affect the ability of ecosystems to provide critical services, such as the provision of clean water, to humans.  Moreover, the LTER Network provides information to managers and policy makers that allow them to manage ecosystem resources sustainably.  The LTER Network Office (LNO) is funded by the National Science Foundation to support the goals of the LTER Network.

Recently, some functions of the LNO were transferred to a new entity, the LTER National Communications Office at the University of California-Santa Barbara, while others remained at the University of New Mexico. Activities supported by this award allowed for a smooth transition between the LNO and the new office. The LNO coordinated a meeting of the LTER Science Council in May, 2015, and organized and carried out the LTER All Scientists Meeting from August 30-September 2, 2015, at the YMCA of the Rockies in Estes Park, CO. The All Scientists Meeting was organized around the theme: "From Long-Term Data to Understanding: Toward a Predictive Ecology". Almost 600 people attended the meeting, and there were over 300 poster presentations and more than 75 formal and ad-hoc working group meetings.   

The LNO worked with staff at the NCO to transfer data and virtual machine images for web pages and other online services to them. All critical communication services were transferred to the NCO by April 30, 2016. In addition, members of the LNO staff continued to curate existing Network datasets, to conduct maintenance and security operations for the Network Information System, and to manage the addition of data generated by sites until a new award was in place to continue these activities.  

Broader Impacts

Outcomes from the All Scientists Meeting included increases in cross-site and Network-level science, an increased pace of development of synthesis products, the formation of new collaborations, the development of new LTER science themes, and better integration of graduate students and new scientists into the LTER community. Continued support of the operations of the NIS increased the amount and variety of ecological data available to the scientific community and other research efforts for comparison and synthesis. The LNO continued to provide leadership in the important areas of data sharing, data standards, connectivity, and the acquisition and implementation of new technologies through our relationships with other distributed networks (e.g., Organization for Biological Field Stations and the International LTER Network) and research programs (e.g., Macrosystems Biology, Long Term Research in Environmental Biology). By facilitating the transition to a new organizational model for the LTER Network, the LNO assured continuous availability of research data and dissemination of information about LTER to scientists, stakeholders, and the public.
